Why are we checking explicitly against 200 for errors?  200 is used for HTTP requests, and we shouldn't be reusing those codes for that.  Arguably a handler could want to return 200 from a websocket route instead of upgrading, so if we're going to allow the concept of "the bmc route rejected the upgrade" we'll need some other flag.

As mentioned in the comment below, the default response of http::response is 200. 
The reason this explicit check is done is because, if everything was smooth and upgradation was done, the response would contain 200, so since the upgradation is already done, we wouldn't need to reply through this connection. That's why calling the else section to destroy this connection.
Incase of any errors, say like privilege check error, we would need to reply through the same connection without upgrading.
So, only unsuccessful messages needs to be communicated through this channel.

Either ways, on success i.e. on upgrade, we wouldn't have this adaptor anymore to send the OK response.

I think flags here will be 1000 and 1001?
If we like to post error info.
right?
https://github.com/Luka967/websocket-close-codes

> upgradation was done, the response would contain 200

Technically if everything worked, we would expect to see a 101 Switching Protocols, right?  I think this is kind of the core of the problem, we're trying to inject behavior post-upgrade that needs to be done pre-upgrade.  Beast handles this already on line 106 of websocket.hpp.  If we need to expose that callback to each individual route, I suspect we need a separate callback from onopen(), because onopen happens after the websocket has been negotiated.
Why do we need to post this?  can't we just call completeRequest directly?
This is the current implementation as seen in line 361.

Hello, Ed 
Do you mean we do not need to return any error info, only close the connection?
Prefer to return early instead of calling else.
We cannot return here as the connection needs to be destroyed. For which CompleteRequestHAndler needs to be set to NULL.
Patchset 2 is a rebase of this change to the latest

This patchset was idle long enough that I've forgotten all context for it.

Lets start with updating this commit message to "why is this necessary" ideally with cases of user-facing behavior that this improves.  From my perspective, websocket routes don't really have good reasons where they need to "fail" at a response level, and can quite easily fail once the connection is already open.  With that said, I'm open to the possibility that this could be needed, so I'm curious what user facing feature this would allow for.

The code that this was originally patching has changed a bit since originally written, so I suspect some of the initial reasoning behind this might not be present anymore, but lets walk through it in the commit message text.

Apologies for late response on this. Commit message will be modified to reflect the actual changes. Meanwhile, Let me clarify the intent of this patch.

This patch is pass the response object to down handlers for upgraded routes ( Note: For normal routes, its already done https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/http/http_connection.hpp#L391) and handle error scenarios. This change is needed for below use cases.

- To add Authorization to all upgrade routes. Today for upgrade routes( Websocket or SSE etc.) we have only authentication, no authorization check. Normal requests its done in handle() (https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/http/routing.hpp#L1304-L1407) for upgrade routes its not there (Ex: /kvm/0/  or /vm/0/0 or /nbd/<> or SSE etc..). So passing asyncResp object will let us allow to adding authorization for upgrade routes. This commit is baby step to towards it.  Adding authorization check for upgrade routes is done at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/46991

 - Some of the upgrade routes may have some extra validation checks (Example: OEM implementation may block KVM session if its crosses x number, Or some OEM check before establishing communication etc..). So passing asyncRes to upgrade start() will allow making few more verification and return response to user. This is extra change added by Abhishek Patel. When i checked that code, i thought can't it be done before creating new connection? Yes, It can be but that requires considerable amount of design changes for all upgrade routes. Passing asyncRes is easy method in doing that ( or may be starting step for it).


Dheeraj, Can you update commit message accordingly.  Also refresh the patch to latest master which has merge conflicts.

Updated commit message to reflect the intent of the patch.
Also, resolved merge conflicts
New patchset doesn't address comments.  Please at least reply to all comments when pushing a new patchset.

this will remove out completeRequestHandler which we 
added. so no idea how to fix that
After I copy the request, I can add that 101 check code. That is one way to solve this.

Checking for 101 code doesn't help in this case.  I really have no idea what you're trying to accomplish with this patchset, so lets start with writing up a commit message for what you want the user-facing behavior to be, then we can work backwards to what the implementation looks like.
Ed, I added a comment in commit message explaining the need and use cases. Can you check and see if if looks fine.
Its being resolved in the latest patch set.
You are calling Response constructor which will create r-value reference, there is no need to std::move this.

This code was added by "Abhishek Patel". 
I guess we are trying to construct a Response object using boost::beast::websocket::response_type, and std::move would prevent another allocation and a copy.
Am i missing something ?

std::move only performs conversion from l-value to r-value. Here you already have r-value reference after calling Response(m).

If it was supposed to move response_type to Response it is not working correctly, it should be: Response(std::move(m)).

This is going to run after async_accept, done here:
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/http/websocket.hpp#L140

This is a problem, because it will lead to cases where the response returns both the connection upgrade headers, AND the error code.  Per the http RFC, we can't be returning both.  We should only be returning the websocket upgrade headers in the cases where we also return 101.

To handle this properly, we need to run the authorization before async_accept.

I think it is more of an OR condition. We would either be returning an error OR the Upgraded connection would take over the adaptor and return respective response.

In the handleUpgrade function of routing.hpp, we return instantly in case of any error(s). So the asyncRes obj would have respective error, and the control wouldn't go till async_accept of websocket. And upon reaching to the above highlighted line(Line 386), we would just return an error. 
In case of success, we aren't returning any response from here. 
The Line 404 is for the success condition where we delete the completion handler.


Regarding auth before async_accept, the patchset https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/46991/ handles it.

This patch is mainly focused to add async support to handleUpgrade.
